content.description:
Non-descript, but worth doing at least once... 

  The online guide gives this one an .8 

  Cobble-hauling up the black streak on the slabby face right of the corner.  The crux comes at a steeper section near the last bolt.  This is one of the longer routes at El Rito.
content.protection: Bolts. B1 is high, but the start is reasonable. The online guide gives this an .8
content.location: Start up the obvious, short pedestal just to the right of the hole.

content.description: Climb up just right of a gash in the wall and right of the arete proper to the high first two bolts. Cross the gash for the third clip. Consider unclipping the second draw at that point to reduce rope drag.  Tiptoe up the face and head right along the arete being careful what holds you use.    A steep middle section ends quickly at a good rest before the steeper finish past a few bolts to a three-bolt anchor with chains and webbing.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a chain and webbing anchor with carabiners. Word on the street is Thanh hand-drilled the bolts! A couple of the holes weren't drilled deep enough (or are in shallow depressions where the hanger doesn't quite fit) and a 1/4" or so of sleeve is visible behind the hangers on those.
content.location: Look for the shiny new bolts ~10 feet left of Electric Pet Gri-Gri.

content.description:
Many great days at El Rito involve the Number Two Red whether you're talking about El Farolito or climbing on Walt's Wall.  

  If you manage to survive the loose, steep approach trail to the base of the route, start with a few moves to get over an initial steep section to the cruiser middle section clipping three bolts along the way. Then climb up steepening cobbles past three more bolts to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor with carabiners.
content.location: This route starts uphill about fifty feet right of Drive-By Genocide just past the big, dead, leaning tree. Hangers are pretty well cammoed so look hard.

content.description:
Climb up vertical rock in a faint gully past three bolts. The angle backs off for the middle but the holds get small enough to still keep it interesting as you aim for the corner above. Clip a bolt out left of the corner and make airy, steeper moves left out of the corner. A few more interesting moves keep it entertaining to the anchor.

 As with all new routes, use caution and look for suspect holds. Assume nothing.
content.protection: 9 bolts to a two bolt anchor with lowering biners. The first bolt and the last four bolts are glue-in bolts.
content.location: The right-most route on the big wall, just before trail drops down into a depression. Easily identifiable by the first bolt, a glue-in bolt.

climbs.name: The NBA
climbs.fa: Theo Takeda, Rob McMurry, Walt Wehner, June 1997

content.description: This route begins climbing up a giant featured slab using gear placements in an incipient crack for the first 30 feet, then cruise up a slightly overhanging wall past four bolts for 30 feet. This route is fairly sustained at the grade, and is often overlooked.
content.protection: Stoppers, Aliens, and quickdraws. 4 bolts to a 2 bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This route is the first one to the right of Walt's Wall Waltz.

content.description: Start up steep but juggy rock to clip the first bolt. The angle backs off immediately past the second bolt and up to the third clip. Pull on steep jugs and then climb as gently as possible through some questionable rock past the fifth and sixth bolts.  Breathe a sigh of relief as you grab the better rock on the arete to the left and finish up easier terrain to the anchor.    The rock in the upper-middle portion of the route is pretty dubious and I was a bit sketched to pull very hard on some of the jugs.
content.protection: 8 bolts with Spanish "lucky" hangers to a two-bolt anchor that's not well equalized.  Needs a few screw links. Rapping the route recommended.
content.location: About 20 feet left of Walt's Wall Waltz on a semi-separate wall.  Easily identifiable by the light brown sketchy rock on the steep part by the fifth and sixth bolts.

content.description:
Non-descript, but worth doing once... 

  The online guide gives this one a .9 

  [First clip is definitely the crux. After that the grade drops significantly. Nice climbing above, big pockets, a bit run-out from bolt 2 to 3, but nothing hazardous because the climbing is easy.]
content.protection: 7 Bolts. The first bolt is pretty high up and the climbing is not trivial to that point. Stick clip recommended. .
content.location: Toward right side of wall.  This one is the 2nd bolted line right of Walt's Waltz

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: Jason Chen, Walt Wehner, and Theo Takeda, 7/1997

content.description: Drive-By Genocide is cool because the finish is really steep for 5.10, with great jugs.  The start is forgettable 5.9 cobble pulling.   The climb is well-protected, though some of the bolts can be hard to find.
content.location: Genocide is up the hill and to the right of the main part of Walt's Wall, just to the right of a tower.

content.description: West facing, tall wall boasting a few good, long moderates. It's the first major wall you'll see on the left as you approach from the parking area.
